Joining me for today's topic "Are Critics Necessary?" are three columnists from the New Yorker: film critic Howard Mintz, art critic Rose Belknap, and Wendy Shields, who reviews books. Let's start with Wendy. No child dreams of becoming a literary critic, so what led you to it?
I wanted anything to do with words. I grew up in a house that was far from peaceful, and books just... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Well, Martin Amis, Toni Morrison, uh...Delia Krauss - Suddenly the other guests go tense, exchanging alarmed glances; Rose looks dumbfounded. They don't use any chemical sprays or fertilizers. I love being up in the tractor, I love the air and the smells, I love dirt. Growing up in the city I always thought dirt was, like, grime. But their dirt is alive, you know, it's rich, it's nourishing --I just want to eat it.

That's a red light. Wendy snaps to attention, looks up: sure enough, she almo went through a RED LIGHT. She jokes to cover up her embarrassment.
Isn't it strange, that red has come to mean "stop" and "danger"? It strikes me that stopping is when you're safe, whereas going is dangerous.

Don't talk, Wendy. When you talk, you don't see. He points her eyes up. The LIGHT IS GREEN. Cars behind HO Wendy drives on, trying to stay focused. DARWAN (cont'd) Get in the left lane. Slow...Signal. WENDY gropes, finds the signal this time. DARWAN (cont'd) Read the signs...See everything...

head_text.subj: STREET AHEAD, PANNING FROM SIDE TO SIDE

text: DARWAN (cont'd) Stop. Watch the light. WENDY'S POV - ON THE RED TRAFFIC LIGHT, then PANNING DOWN
TED (FANTASY) crossing the intersection ahead with his ar around a YOUNG WOMAN.
Ted...! (CONTINUED)

Ted and the Young Woman pass from sight. Then Wendy turns head and... TED IS THERE BESIDE HER WINDOW, gazing at her impassively WENDY (cont'd) Don't you love me anymore? He shakes his head: no. WENDY (cont'd) But why? How did I fail you? What should I have done? When he opens his mouth to speak, the voice is Indian- accented.
(DARWAN'S VOICE)
Pay attention!
Ted is gone, Darwan is beside her.
The light. He's pointing up to the GREEN LIGHT. Rattled, she tromps on the pedal and the CAR LEAPS FORWAR DARWAN BRAKES on his side. The car avoids hitting a JAYWA with his iPod on loud.
Oh my God! She drops her hands to her lap helplessly with a GROAN of frustration; lowers her head.
Why didn't you see him? (beat) Were you wandering?
(looks up) I'm never going to be good at this.
Every time it will get easier. Now, drive on. (CONTINUED)
(in a child's voice) I can't.
Take the wheel. Press the pedal. She puts her hands on the wheel, then shakes her head no.

head_text.subj: THE VIEW THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD GOES BLURRY

text: WATERY...Is it raining? No, it's: WENDY'S EYES FILLING UP WITH TEARS.
Can you drive me home?

(firm) No. You will do it, and I will help. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” DAY 38 Darwan and his nephew Preet huddle around his cell phone. Darwan is talking to his sister RASBIR (Preet's mother, m 40's) on FaceTime: she is seen in closeup on the phone's screen.
She's not young but she can still have one or two children.
Why hasn't she been married?
She was engaged once but the police shot her fiance, just like they did to our Sameer. Then her father was ill for a long time and needed her at home. Now he's dead and she has nowhere to go.
(to Darwan) She's perfect!
She's the best one for you, Darwan. And very nice-looking. Did you like the photo? (CONTINUED)
Yes, but can I talk to her and see her like we're doing?
She won't come to the phone. She thinks you'll see she's too old. She says, "He won't like me."
He won't, Mommy!
I'll think about it. Rasbir, please...take the phone to the window. Show me the street, the sun, the sky, everything.
(shakes her head sadly) Bahpe [brother], it's night time here. (MORE )
(CONTINUED)
RASBIR (cont'd) EXT. HIGH LINE FICKR POOL вЂ” DAY 38B Wendy and her sister DEBBIE pick up their SHWARMA lunch f a FOOD TRUCK.
Well hallelujah, sis, itвЂ™s about time you learned to drive.

IвЂ™m just doing it for Tasha, not because I need to. As they move to a pair of wooden chaises to sit and eat: WENDY (CONTвЂ™D) (contвЂ™d) But you have to drive, Debbie, you're in the suburbs. Here I have the subway, buses, taxis... (they sit) I also used to have a husband who drove.
(shakes her head) Ted. Such a creep - but you know? I can believe it. On my street alone we've had three divorces caused by philandering.
(starts eating) Oh well, Greenwich.

(inspecting the shwarma) What I don't understand is: how can they cheat on their wives and still live with themselves? I mean, it's like pissing in the pool. Maybe nobody saw you do it, but you know the yellow's in the water. And you have to swim around in it, pretending it's clean. Debbie manages to give Wendy the giggles.
And how do they find all these sluts? Is there a vending machine? (CONTINUED)
I call them Play-Doh Bunnies. The guys can mold them into whatever they want. Teach them tricks. Like waking them up every morning with a blowjob.
(sad again) Maybe that's all Ted ever really wanted.
(tries a bite of the shwarma ) Honestly, it's nirvana for them.
(mouth full) Then why don't we do it?
It's too much work. Why do you think they call it a job? The two break up, laughing harder and harder, trying to k their food from flying out of their mouths.
Wendy meets with her divorce ATTORNEY at a table in an em conference room. He raises
He wants "support"?!

Or a twenty-five percent share of your income. He claims he supported you while you pursued your career. I know, I know -- a hand to forestall her rage; it doesn't work. She POUNDS the table with her fist.
This is a man who was jealous of my career! Who criticized everything I did, to undermine me! (CONTINUED)
Wendy, it's normal. Each side asks for the outrageous, and they come together in the middle. Don't take it personally. (CONTINUED)

Don't take it - ha! Ha ha ha ha! Just give him everything! If he agrees to be castrated. He waits for her to finish venting. His CELL PHONE VIBRAT on the table. He glances at the ID, then checks his notes
He'll let you stay in the house if you buy him out.
I can't possibly afford that.
Or split fifty-fifty if you sell.
I have to move out?! I am that house. It's like asking me to move out of me.
Maybe it's too big now?
I can't believe this. It's where we raised Tasha, where we were happy....

Her voice trails off. She realizes the word "happy" is no moot. Obsolete. WENDY (cont'd) Okay. It's where we were idiots, and squandered our marriage, and never made love when we should have and never fought when we should have, and we read and read and read and went totally fucking blind - and I want my house! I want to stay where I am!

Returning to his apartment, Darwan sees an American MAN leaning against a black CAR parked in front. Waiting. Something about him makes Darwan tense up instinctively.  4l 8/21/13 31. INT. OUTSIDE DARWAN'S APARTMENT - SECONDS LATER вЂ”- MAGI Pausing outside his door, Darwan hears MEN'S VOICES withi speaking English. TIGHT ON DARWAN - His face is suddenly bathed in sweat, h breathing ragged. XCU - HIS HAND goes slowly to the door knob. Before he ca turn it: THE DOOR BANGS OPEN. Two of Darwan's Sikh Roommates emerg escorted roughly by two official-looking men (IMMIGRATION AGENTS). His roommates look at Darwan with helpless dread they are rushed past. A third AGENT brings up the rear, stopping short when he Darwan.
(flashes badge to Darwan) I.N.S. Who're you?
I am Darwan Singh. American citizen.
Let's see your papers. With unsteady hands, Darwan removes his driver's license his wallet. The Agent examines it. AGENT (cont'd) How come they let you in, Darwan?
Political asylum.

(checks the year) 2000...you got in just under the wire. The Agent brusquely hands back the license and exits. Left alone, Darwan rushes into the living room. His roommates' half-finished tea stands on the table. An INDI SOAP OPERA still plays on the TV. The closets stand open, their contents strewn on the floor, the sofa upended, indicating a forcible search of the premises. (CONTINUED)

(to himself; frantic) Preet... There's a faint NOISE on the other side of a wall. DARWAN (cont'd) Preet! INT. BATHROOM вЂ”- BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” CONTINUOUS - DA As Darwan rushes in, the cabinet door under the sink THRO OPEN. Preet is inside, extricating himself from the vanit where he hid by contorting himself into an impossibly tig ball. He spills onto the bath mat, one foot still stuck i the plumbing. Darwan helps him up.
(shaken) I thought they got me this time.
They took Teji and Raam. Thank God you're safe.

Only 'til next time. INT. BEDROOM вЂ” BASEMENT APARTMENT - A LITTLE LATER вЂ” The bedroom's a mess, too, from the agents' search: cloth all over the floor and the bed upended. Preet stuffs his belongings into a duffel while Darwan pleads with him.
I'll find us another place -
I'm going to live with my girlfriend in Chinatown.
(taken aback) You have a girlfriend?
They won't look for me if I'm with her. She's Jewish. (off Darwan's shock) Uncle D, you knew I would go sometime. (CONTINUED)
This is a very poor decision. My sister will blame me.

I tell her, Mom, this is America. I can do what I want. As long as they don't ask for my papers. INT. LIVING ROOM вЂ” BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- LATER вЂ” MA Darwan is left alone in the dishevelled apartment. He mak no move to clean up. As night falls, he remains leaning against the wall, thinking.

Darwan sits in prayer. His attention is drawn to: AN OLDER SIKH MAN praying with his WIFE alongside him. Th lips move together. EXT. WENDY'S HOUSE вЂ” DAY 46 Darwan waits in the student car in his customary spot, pa at the hydrant in front of Wendy's house. A lovesick INDI BALLAD plays on his radio. He hardly hears it, still deep thought. Wendy bursts from the house, her hair chaotic, glowering anger over her divorce.
The student car creeps through Harlem to Washington Heigh Wendy's attention is everywhere but the road.
Point your eyes at the middle of the lane. The same as a gun. Your peripheral vision sees all the rest. ANGLE - PASSING A PAIR OF STREET TOUGHS. They spot Darwan with his turban.
(yells) Osama! Thought we killed you! (CONTINUED)
The Kid HIT the hood of the car as it stops at the crossw
(YELLS out window) Shut up, asshole! (to Darwan) Does that happen to you a lot?

Every day. People try to push your buttons. You don't engage with them. Especially when you drive. She comes to a stop at the intersection. DARWAN (cont'd) You are on top of the crosswalk. Next time stop where you can see the lines. ON WENDY - grits her teeth. The constant stream of critic even delivered in Darwan's neutral tone, is getting to he Traffic moves again. Suddenly a SPORTS CAR ZOOMS past, an abruptly in front of her, inches from the bumper, cutting off. Wendy POUNDS THE HORN.
God damn it!
Don't lean on the horn. It's not a boat. Just a short tap.
Why do men have to do that? Wag their balls in your face.
(controls his shock) I think it is time to discuss road rage. You must learn to be calm and relaxed, not only to drive but in your life as well.
And how do you manage that?
Prayer helps me. I pray every day. (CONTINUED)
I unfriended God a long time ago... Guess you've got lots of friends up there. All those gods of yours.
I am not Hindu. I am a Sikh. We have only one God, like yours.
Then I'm mad at your God, too. He says nothing. She turns her head to glance at him. He' impassive, as if he didn't hear her, focusing only on the road. WENDY (cont'd) I'm sorry.
Eyes forward.
The car passes through the narrow tree-lined streets of CASTLE VILLAGE. TUDOR HOUSES. A RABBI crosses the street; ELDERLIES walk their DOGS, KIDS in Catholic uniforms retu from school.

Be careful to see every person before you. They may not have the right of way but you are the one driving a deadly weapon... He looks over. Wendy has a glazed look he has come to kno well. She doesn't notice she's rolling right through a ST SIGN. DARWAN'S HAND WRENCHES THE WHEEL FROM HER. THE CAR pulls over to the curb. DARWAN (cont'd) Where were you just now? You don't seem to notice anything. Observation, Wendy, observation. This is your weakness.
(snaps ) Are you channeling my husband? (CONTINUED)
Tell me why you want to drive.
To go somewhere else.
And how do you want to get there?
(off-guard) "How"?
You want to arrive in one piece? Or two pieces? Or three?
(looks away; haughtily) Don't patronize me.

Look at me. The urgency in his voice makes her turn back to him. She surprised to see the depth of compassion in his eyes, although she has spent the lesson baiting him. DARWAN (cont'd) It doesn't matter what is going on in your life out there, you must shut it out. When you are here, when you are at the wheel of a car, this is all there is. Your life: right now. So take care of it,
please. FADE OUT.
Wendy opens the door for a CLEANING CREW.
Darwan unlocks the door to basement apartment. LATER - Working shirtless, runs a dry vacuum over the floor...cuts and lays carpet.... He hangs a mirror...a shower curtain... (CONTINUED)
Preet helps him haul a king-size mattress through the door....
The cleaners attack the house. Wendy tosses clutter into garbage bags... KNOCK-KNOCK 0O.S.
Darwan opens the door, and his FRIENDS lug in boxes of electronic equipment.

Wendy lets the cleaners out. She turns: everything is nea and spotless. INT. WENDY'S BEDROOM - LATER вЂ” DAY 54 Standing before the mirror, Wendy checks her dress. It lo new. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” LATER вЂ” DAY 55

It's done. A big FLAT-SCREEN TV is perched on a cabinet a with a DVD PLAYER, SPEAKERS and SUB-WOOFER. Everyone's ve excited. Darwan plays with four remotes, trying to turn t TV on. At last, the image ignites on the screen. DING-DONG 0O.S. The doorbell.
Wendy opens the door. It's Ted. Apparently she's been expecting him.
Hi. He's braced for a fight, but instead she smiles cheerily.
Come on in. (CONTINUED)
He steps in, registering surprise at her makeover.
You look fine.
Therefore I am. INT. LIVING ROOM, WENDY'S HOUSE - LATER вЂ”- DAY 57 Ted's reaching down his books from the bookcase, filling cartons. Wendy is curled up on the couch, watching.
Do you think books miss their owners? They pine, they waste away?
Or they get a new haircut and hit the singles scene.

So many choices, when you're single. He's silent, won't touch that, his back to her as he reac more books down. WENDY (cont'd) Should I look for a two or three- bedroom apartment? High-rise or low- rise?
We're looking for a place in Nyack. She shifts uncomfortably, her heart sinking.
That's a long commute.
I enjoy the drive. I love a big bridge over a big river. Human genius vaulting over the primeval ooze.
Really. (re: books) You're leaving me "The Joy of Sex"? (CONTINUED)
It's yours. I gave it to you for Valentine's.
I don't remember reading it.
You put it in a drawer.

Well, toss it here. (he does) Let's see if there's anything we didn't cover. (checks table of contents) Missionary, check. Standing, check. Rear entry, check. Wait. Did we do "The Viennese Oyster"? Without responding, he hefts a carton and exits.
Ted finishes loading his double-parked car with cartons.
When Ted re-enters, Wendy has put a box full of photograp on the coffee table.
Guess that's it.
Here're some photos I found, you might want.
I'm double-parked. Wendy's smiling at a photo she's picked from the pile.
This one's from Moose River. Lured over, he sits beside her on the couch as she hands the photo. He grins at the image.
Natasha was what, six? (CONTINUED)
She was eight, the cabin was six. Degrees below zero.
(LAUGHS )
First and last camping trip. (re: next photo) Halloween?
(swats him playfully) No! Shoulder pads were in then. Ted looks at a few more pictures. Wendy watches him carefully. Sighing, he puts them down, suddenly deflated.
This is hard.
Yes. Beat. WENDY (cont'd) I'm finding I can do hard things. I'm learning to drive, you know.
That's a scary thought, Miss McGoo.

I can drive, I can keep a clean house, I can doll myself up, I can bake a cherry pie... She slides to her knees in front of him. WENDY (cont'd) I can give you what you need. He's frozen, unsure this is really happening, as she reac to undo his belt buckle. WENDY (cont'd) I can make you love me again.
Wendy -- this just isn't you. She smiles seductively, parting his fly. (CONTINUED)
Why not me?
(laughs nervously) Since when did you become lapdancer? She reaches inside his pants and bends her head...He pull her hands away from his open fly. TED (cont'd) Sweetheart, don't...

God! To hear you call me that again is wonderful. She goes for his mouth, bringing her lips to his -- O.S. BEEP-BEEP-BEEP: a truck backing up on the street outside; then the ROAR OF HEAVY MACHINERY. Ted bounds off couch.
Holy shit!
The OPERATOR of a city TOW TRUCK is just putting the big in Ted's front bumper. Ted runs into the street, YELLING in protest. WENDY IN THE DOORWAY watches, demoralized...then shuts th door.
No. No. She is not this kind of woman. 61 INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- QUEENS вЂ” DAY 61
PREET and his Uncle are sitting in the apartment looking through a lingerie catalog at women dressed in scanty panties, saucy push-up bras, peekaboo satin nighties...
How do you know? (CONTINUED)
She will be modest, I think. This would shock her.
Trust me! All women, they want these things.
No.
(follows, teasing) And what about you, Uncle D? Don't you want it?
I don't want her to get the idea that this is how I think of her. It's disrespectful.
(exasperated GROAN) It's bad enough you don't understand women. But you don't even understand yourself.
I'll wait for her birthday. EXT. WENDY'S STREET -вЂ” DAY 62 ANGLE ON TIRES of student car ROLLING BACKWARD slowly.... They swivel sharply, still backing up...then with a JOLT, THEY MOUNT THE CURB.
Oh shit, oh shit...!
Wendy leans her head against the wheel in frustration. (CONTINUED)
I'm so lost. Darwan taps her on the back gently. She turns to him.
Wendy, how do you know if you've put in enough salt and pepper when you are making a beef stew?
You taste it?
Right. So what do you do if you've lost track of the way the car is pointing when you parallel-park?
You taste it?
You just let the car move back a tiny bit and see which way it goes -- you taste the direction.
And then you correct the seasoning?

Right. You adjust a little bit, and a little bit -- and now I've made myself hungry. I will go home and make myself a curry. She smiles wanly, preoccupied. DARWAN (cont'd) You look very nice today. She looks at him as if seeing a man for the first time.
Thank you.
He writes her receipt on the hood of the car while she wr a check. As they make the exchange, he looks as if he wan to say something but has lost his courage. Then he blurts (CONTINUED)
Wendy...what does a woman like for a gift?
I don't know, candy, flowers... Speaking for myself, a book of poetry.
(brightens ) Ah!...
My husband gave me that on our first date and every anniversary. He'd mark a certain love poem and ask me to read it while he lay his head in my lap. (wistfully) It was the perfect gift.
Yes, a fine idea.
(rips check out of book) What about you? What present do you like?
(LAUGHS; accepts it) A check, of course. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT -вЂ” NIGHT 64 Darwan carefully wraps a small book in gift paper.

He puts the final touches on his new home, hanging a pict of the Sikhs' Golden Temple; another of the First Guru, father of Sikhism. PAN TOWARD THE LAST PICTURE he's hanging: of his parents, FATHER posed stiffly, proud in his white turban; HIS MOTH languidly leaning her head on her hand and smiling warmly INT. LIVING ROOM вЂ” WENDY'S HOUSE - NIGHT 65
ANGLE ON MOROCCAN TABLE LAMP with ornate stained glass sh (CONTINUED)

(into phone) How can you claim the Moroccan lamp as a pre-marital asset?! WIDEN ANGLE TO INCLUDE - WENDY pacing with the cordless phone, and brandishing a page from a legal document. WENDY (cont'd) (into phone) We bought it together, Ted! (tears page in half) Hear that? I'm tearing this in half. Now you can shove it up both your ass and your lawyer's!

It's a sweltering day: muggy, yellowish sky. Even with th windows rolled down, Darwan and Wendy are drenched in swe She drives east along Central Park South, passing SKATEBOARDERS with their shirts off; JOGGERS pouring Evia over their heads; mobs of CHILDREN around the ICE CREAM SELLER. HORSES with drooping heads hauling carriages of TOURISTS. A PEDI-CAB DRIVER pedals stoically in the heat alongside her.
Why don't you have air-conditioning in this heap?

The school buys the cheapest cars. I will take you someplace cooler. He smiles mysteriously. EXT. 59TH STREET вЂ”- MINUTES LATER вЂ” DAY 67 Wendy waits in heavy traffic at a stoplight. Looking ahea she realizes that the street ascends straight into...
Oh my God! It's a bridge!
Yes. Today you are going over a bridge. (CONTINUED)
The LIGHT CHANGES. But Wendy is frozen.
I can't!
Just keep going. (CONTINUED)
The car behind her BLASTS its horn angrily.
I'm afraid of heights!
We'll take it slowly. Now go straight.
Please don't make me do it. The HONKING GROWS as more cars join in.

Wendy, you must move. The car creeps forward. The LIGHT CHANGES before she has reached the opposite side of the intersection. Now the CR TRAFFIC APPROACHES and she's "blocking the box." More HONKING. Wendy and Darwan shout above the noise:
Why are you forcing me to do this?!

Because I know what you can do better than you! His calm obstinacy infuriates her, but there's no choice: must drive ahead, and that means mounting the bridge. Her fingers tighten on the wheel. GREEN LIGHT. She drives forward, slow as a tortoise.
The student car creeps over the bridge, the East River stretched out below.
Don't look down. Focus on the center of the lane, and it's just another road. Except it's in the sky. Think of yourself as a bird. You are floating on the wind. Feel how happy it is, how easy --
Darwan, this is terrifying!! (CONTINUED)
Fear is a good thing. If you are afraid, then you will pay more attention. No more tuning out, Wendy.
They've arrived in Queens. Wendy is a wreck.
Congratulations. You can let go the death grip now.
Oh my God, I never want to do that again!
But you have to drive back.
No, you will drive us back.
No way. I'm happy here in Queens. EXT. QUEENS - SEQUENCE OF SHOTS вЂ” DAY 70
MONTAGE OF QUEENS NEIGHBORHOODS, as Wendy drives through; Darwan and Wendy converse O.S.

Queens is part of New York, too. PASSING an Asian district, where throngs of SHOPPERS stro under signs in Chinese, Thai, Singaporean, Malaysian; pas karaoke bars, Chinese herb shops... DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) We don't have skyscrapers and Times Square and Trump palaces. We only have...more people. PASSING the "African Poetry Theater," PEOPLE on the stree wear dashikis and doo-rags... DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) Many different people. Families. (CONTINUED)
You have your family here, too?

Just my nephew, my sister's son. She lives in Punjab. PASSING under the arcade of the elevated subway line, we LATINOS -- Filipino, Ecuadorian, Peruvian -- on the stree open produce markets with Spanish signs...
Your parents? PASSING A PARK where a group of East INDIANS have gathere a small stream, scattering a deceased person's ashes.
They're dead. OUT THE WINDOW - TAIWANESE KIDS flying MODEL PLANES in th park. PAN UP TO SEE A JUMBO JET ROAR low above the treetops, he for JFK Airport...
Wendy swerves the car onto a small street of huddled cottages: a working-class neighborhood.
(frowns ) I didn't tell you to turn.
(grins) I'm showing you my Queens. This is where I grew up.

You're from Queens?! After a double-take, he bursts out LAUGHING. DARWAN (cont'd) You played a good joke on me. WENDY'S POV - PASSING an old heap at the curb. In the driver's seat is a MAN in a Mets' cap, smoking. (CONTINUED)

Dad used to sit in his car, just like that, listening to the ball game on the radio, whenever my mother kicked him out of the house. Which was pretty often. He took off one day and we never saw him again. My sister and I were left alone to raise our mother. Wendy picks up some speed as she continues talking. WENDY (cont'd) -.-I had scoliosis so I had to spend a year in a cast in bed. That's when I got into books. They were my ride. Darwan takes his eyes off the road to watch her in profil WENDY (cont'd) "Smarty Wendypants" he called me. He would've been proud to see me go to Barnard. SEAGULLS are in the air. The car is headed for the beache Far Rockaway. MANHATTAN is seen across the water, with it clutter of skyscrapers, through heat haze... WENDY (cont'd) I can't believe you got me here. I'm allergic to Queens.
There will be a reward.

head_text.subj: INT/EXT STUDENT CAR- BOARDWALK, FAR ROCKAWAY

text: Wendy parks in the lot near the boardwalk, and the long s of beach where the whole MELTING POT of Queens comes to l in the sand and play in the waves. Wendy relinquishes the wheel with a GROAN.
(jumping out of the car) Wait here. (CONTINUED)
ON WENDY - watching him stride onto the boardwalk. She tu the RADIO on, tuning it until she gets a BASEBALL GAME. S smiles to herself, then looks up. (CONTINUED)
WENDY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD (FANTASY) - A man in a Mets' cap stands in front of the bumper, smiling back at It's WENDY'S FATHER, as she imagines him.
Hi, Dad. Well, here I am. Sitting in your seat, and the Mets are playing Arizona.
Good for you, Wendypants . About time you took the wheel. WE PAN TO THE PASSENGER SEAT, where her father has reappeared, sitting beside her.

(pats the dashboard) A car's the greatest thing in the history of human invention. Forget your house, you could move in here. Sleep in the back. Heat up a TV dinner in the engine. Here's your shower. He switches on the WIPER FLUID, spraying the front window She GIGGLES. WENDY'S FATHER (cont'd) Pee in the gas tank. And when the spirit moves, you just drive away. ON WENDY - not laughing anymore.
Like you drove away, Dad? And never came back. A KNOCK ON THE DRIVER'S WINDOW makes her turn her head. Darwan is there, holding two ice cream bars.
Here is your reward. EXT. BEACH - LATER вЂ” DAY 74 TRACK WITH WENDY AND DARWAN eating ICE CREAM BARS as they stroll away from the SUNBATHERS.
You have a masters, really? (CONTINUED)
I was a university professor, like my father.
Then why do you teach driving?
For a better job I would have to take off my turban, shave my beard. People think I look dangerous. But this is how I know who I am. And here it is too easy to forget.
Don't you go back for visits?
I can never go home to India. It's part of political asylum. I could not see my father before he died last year.
I didn't get a chance to say goodbye to my dad either.
I missed my mother's funeral, too, but that was when I was in prison there.
(taken aback) Why?

For nothing. For being a Sikh. The police had already killed my brother. They said he was a terrorist, and they had to shoot him because he ambushed them, but it was a lie. Then they punished the rest of the family. All of us were tortured, my father, my uncle, even my mother. They let my sister alone because she was too young. Back then there was no justice for Sikhs.
How long were you in prison? (CONTINUED)
A long time. 8/21/13 51A. (CONTINUED)

His tone is carefully placid, but a shadow passes over hi face. He stares at the waves. Wendy can tell the subject closed. He returns to the present, as if switching something off. DARWAN (cont'd) But here is the ocean. Punjab is nowhere near water. The SKY HAS GONE DARK. RUMBLING O.S. A summer THUNDERSTOR gathering. Darwan glances at his watch, suddenly alarmed. DARWAN (cont'd) It's very late!
